Award.AbstractNarration:
This research takes an information theoretic approach to understanding principles that govern a coordinated rate-efficient sampling of multiple signals and centralized compression of the sampled subset. The goal is to reconstruct the entirety of the signals within acceptable distortion levels. The research has three main components: an integrated analysis of sampling and rate distortion behavior, and their tradeoffs; sampling rate distortion theory for Markov random fields; and sampling rate distortion performance for signals with memory. Expected outcomes are a characterization of fundamental performance limits of optimum sampling rate and lossy compression rate and their interplay, together with the best choice of sampling mechanisms and attendant processing for reconstruction.

The investigators' technical approach involves the development of a principle of "sampling rate distortion" which lies at the intersection of specialities in information theory and signal processing, and has the larger objective of elucidating material connections between sampling and rate distortion performance. The performance of specific sampling and rate distortion processing schemes will be investigated. Specific groups of open problems chosen for investigation address a general class of multisignal models for sampling and lossy data compression. These are motivated by potential applications including dynamic thermal management for on-chip temperature control during runtime; network function computation; and image restoration, surface reconstruction and visual integration in computer vision.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A new information theoretic approach has been developed for understanding principles that govern the coordinated spatial sampling of correlated temporal signals and centralized lossy compression of the sampled signals. The overarching goal of the processing has been to reconstruct all the signals within acceptable distortion levels. An emergent theory of sampling rate distortion provides a framework for characterizing the fundamental performance limits of optimum sampling rate and lossy compression methods and their interplay, together with the best choice of sampling sets and processing for reconstruction. Potential applications include dynamic thermal management for onchip temperature control during runtime; network function computation; and image restoration, surface reconstruction and visual integration in computer vision.

 
The main distinguishing feature of the completed project is an integrated theoretical understanding of  sampling and rate distortion behavior, and their tradeoffs.  At the intersection of specialities in information theory and signal processing, the projected yielded results that elucidate material connections between sampling and rate distortion performance. Furthermore, it created advances in information theory through the introduction of new models and concepts. Outcomes include: a characterization of fundamental performance limits and the structure of optimal sampling and lossy compression techniques of pertinence to theory and engineering practice; and development of new methodologies for lossy data compression with inherent signal parameter estimation techniques. Furthermore, new connections emerged to probability distribution learning (in statistical learning theory) and correlated multiarmed bandit problems (in machine learning), inspiring future research.

 

The completed project, which has a home in information theory, had rich points of contact with areas of signal processing and computer vision through classical sampling and quantization and signal recovery from incomplete data. These connections provided a valuable learning environment for graduate students. Specifically, the basic elements of the technical approach were discussed in special topics seminars and conference tutorial presentations with the participation of faculty researchers, graduate students and postdoctoral researchers. The project involved interactions with researchers in academia and industry specializing in data compression, statistical inference and machine learning. Results were disseminated in multiple forums in the fields of information theory and signal processing.
